TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit NavigatingCancelEventArgs extends System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs

remarks.format:
## Remarks These event arguments contain information about the navigation that was requested, and are passed to handlers of the **Navigating** event, which is implemented by the following:
- <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigating?displayProperty=nameWithType>
- <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationWindow.Navigating?displayProperty=nameWithType>
- <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Frame.Navigating?displayProperty=nameWithType>
- <xref:System.Windows.Application.Navigating?displayProperty=nameWithType>
<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs> encapsulates the following details of the navigation request:
- **Navigation Initiation**: <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.NavigationMode%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Navigator%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.IsNavigationInitiator%2A>.
- **Navigation Content**: <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Uri%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Content%2A>.
- **Navigation Request**: <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationFailedEventArgs.WebRequest%2A>.
- **Navigation State**: <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ExtraData%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ContentStateToSave%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.TargetContentState%2A>.
This information allows you to both evaluate the nature of the navigation request, and view and update specified request details before navigation occurs.
Based on the navigation request information provided by <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs>, or based on application-specific state or code, you can completely prevent navigation by setting the <xref:System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs.Cancel%2A> property to `true` (by default, <xref:System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs.Cancel%2A> is `false`).
## Examples The following example shows how to handle <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigating> to detect whether a request to refresh static content was made, and if one was, how to cancel the request.
<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigating>.
[!code-csharp[NavigationServiceSnippets#MainWindowNavigatingCODE](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/NavigationServiceSnippets/CSharp/MainWindow.xaml.cs#mainwindownavigatingcode)] [!code-vb[NavigationServiceSnippets#MainWindowNavigatingCODE](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/NavigationServiceSnippets/visualbasic/mainwindow.xaml.vb#mainwindownavigatingcode)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Content As Object
public: property System::Object ^ Content { System::Object ^ get(); };

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the content object that is being navigated to.
Docs.value: A reference to the content object that is being navigated to; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You can navigate to content using either a uniform resource identifier (URI) or an object. When navigating to an object, which occurs when calling <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> and <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Content%2A> contains a reference to the content object that is being navigated to. Additionally, the <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Uri%2A> property will be `null`.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Windows::Navigation::CustomContentState ^ ContentStateToSave { System::Windows::Navigation::CustomContentState ^ get(); void set(System::Windows::Navigation::CustomContentState ^ value); };

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")
set: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the object that is associated with the back navigation history entry for the page being navigated from.
Docs.value: The object that is associated with the back navigation history entry for the page being navigated from.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigating> event is raised when navigating from one piece of content to another. The content that is being navigated from is added to back navigation history. You can set <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ContentStateToSave%2A> with a custom <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState> object to associate state information with content in navigation history.

public: property System::Object ^ ExtraData { System::Object ^ get(); };

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets the optional data that was passed when navigation started.
Docs.value: The optional data that was passed when navigation started.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ExtraData%2A> can be used to pass context-specific data that is specific to a particular navigation. <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ExtraData%2A> contains a reference to the object that is passed as the second argument when calling either <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>. Otherwise, it is `null`.

Docs.summary: Indicates whether the navigator (, ) that is specified by is servicing this navigation, or whether a parent navigator is doing so.
Docs.value: A value that is if the navigator that is specified by is servicing this navigation. Otherwise, is returned, such as during a nested navigation.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property NavigationMode As NavigationMode

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates the type of navigation that is occurring.
Docs.value: A value that indicates the type of navigation that is occurring.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The types of navigation that can occur are:
- Navigating to new content (<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode.New>).
- Navigating to the previous item in back navigation history (<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode.Back>).
- Navigating to the next item in forward navigation history (<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode.Forward>).
- Refreshing existing content (<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode.Refresh>).

public: property System::Object ^ Navigator { System::Object ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: The navigator that raised this event.
Docs.value: An that is the navigator that raised this event

remarks.format: ## Remarks While <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Navigator%2A> stores a reference to the navigator that raised this event, the navigator may not have actually initiated the navigation. To determine whether this navigator did initiate the current navigation, inspect the <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.IsNavigationInitiator%2A> property.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.TargetContentState%2A> will contain a <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState> object if navigating to content in back or forward navigation history that has a <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState> object associated with it.

Docs.summary: Gets the uniform resource identifier (URI) for the content being navigated to.
Docs.value: The for the content being navigated to. If navigating to an object, is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You can navigate to content using either an uniform resource identifier (URI) or an object. When navigating to an URI, which occurs when calling <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> and <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Uri%2A> contains the URI of the content being navigated to. Additionally, the <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Content%2A> property will be `null`.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property WebRequest As WebRequest
public: property System::Net::WebRequest ^ WebRequest { System::Net::WebRequest ^ get(); };

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets the object that is used to request the specified content.
Docs.value: Gets the object that is used to request the specified content.

remarks.format:
## Remarks <xref:System.Net.WebRequest?displayProperty=nameWithType> is an abstract base class that encapsulates a Web request, and is protocol agnostic. For each common protocol, the .NET Framework includes a class that derives from <xref:System.Net.WebRequest?displayProperty=nameWithType> and extends it with protocol specific state and behavior, including:
- <xref:System.IO.Packaging.PackWebRequest>: URIs that use the `pack://` scheme to request application data files (see [WPF Application Resource, Content, and Data Files](/dotnet/framework/wpf/app-development/wpf-application-resource-content-and-data-files)).
- <xref:System.Net.HttpWebRequest>: URIs that use the `http://` scheme to request files from Web servers.
- <xref:System.Net.FtpWebRequest>: URIs that use the `ftp://` scheme to request files from FTP servers.
- <xref:System.Net.FileWebRequest>: URIs that use the `file://` scheme to request local files.
You can both view and modify <xref:System.Net.WebRequest> details.
<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.WebRequest%2A> is `null` when navigation occurs by:
- Using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.WebBrowser> control.
- Calling <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A>
- Setting <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Content%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.
- Navigating through HTML content in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Frame>.
